docs.lead_paragraph: The United States signaled impatience with the Syrian opposition-in-exile and said it would support a more robust movement to oust President Bashar al-Assad.
docs.abstract: Sec of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, as part of the United States' most aggressive attempt yet to reshape Syrian opposition,  dismisses opposition group Syrian National Council as out-of-touch exiles who should be replaced; hundreds of opposition figures plan to gather in Doha, Quatar, to form new leadership, ostensibly under auspices of Arab League but Clinton says she had been heavily involved in the planning.

byline.original: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MICHAEL R. GORDON
byline.contributor: Neil MacFarquhar reported from Beirut, and Michael R. Gordon from Zagreb, Croatia. Hania Mourtada and Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, and Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

headline.print_headline: As Fighting Rages in Syria, Clinton Seeks New Opposition Movement
headline.main: As Fighting Rages, Clinton Seeks New Syrian Opposition
headline.seo: As Fighting Rages in Syria, Clinton Calls for New Opposition Movement

docs.lead_paragraph: As Democrats gathered in Charlotte, N.C., Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has been doing what she has done throughout President Obama’s term: forswearing partisan politics.
docs.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is wrapping up a tour through Asia, watches the Democratic National Convention from afar, seeking to forswear partisan politics for the sake of her job; despite her announcement that she will step down at the end of Pres Obama's first term, some speculate whether she will consider running for office again in 2016.

headline.print_headline: Not by Design, Another Clinton Watches a Convention From Afar
headline.main: Not by Design, Another Clinton Watches a Convention From Afar
headline.seo: Hillary Rodham Clinton Watches Convention From Afar
